utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: What brings you in?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Hi Faiha, I've been very concerned lately. This past week I, first just started having this really bad headache and then my body, just completely all started hurting after completely rest, and then three days ago I just started having a lot of chills and I had a pretty high fever, just two days ago of almost like I think it was like 38 or 39, yeah, I was just very concerned and I came here today.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: Yeah, it's good that you came in. Lets rewind a little bit and get a full history. So you said the, what started first, the fever or the headache?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: So, the headache started first, so that was around four days ago.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: And three days ago, like my body just started aching all over the place and then just two days ago I noticed that I had a fever and I've been getting a fever since then, as well, like even today, I was having chills.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK, OK, and you said your highest recorded temperature was 39?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Like 38 to 39.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK, so headache started four days ago. Is it persistent or constant or does it come and go?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: It was pretty constant, the headache kind of got better yesterday but last few days it's just been constant headache Pretty much every day.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK, OK. Does anything make it better or worse?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Just some rest and, uh, I tried to take some Tylenol to get rid of it, took some Advil as well. It did help a little bit, but it just kind of came back after the medication wore out.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: How long does the headache last when you get it?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: If I don't take medications, it can last honestly, the whole day.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK, yeah, um, and if you were to describe it, is it sharp, dull, achy?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: It's just achy and it's kind of all over the front of my forehead.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK.

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Sometimes it's just like a throbbing pain.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK, and, alright, and you said it's mostly at the front of your head. How about near the Crown of your head, temples?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: It can go to the temples sometimes, but mostly it's my forehead.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK, OK, and severity-wise 1 to 10, 10 being the worst headache you've ever, worst pain you've ever felt. How bad is it?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Right now it's not that bad, probably like a two or three, but when it was, just a few days ago, it was like probably an 8 or 9.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: Yeah, and then have you ever experienced something like this before?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: No, I'm not usually one to get headaches. My wife, she gets migraines, but like I rarely ever have headaches.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: Yeah, OK, and then you mentioned the headache is getting a little bit better now?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Yeah, the headache has improved a bit, the body aches are still there and the fever is still there but like the headaches I feel have gone down.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK, alright. Have you had any fainting spells or dizziness?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: No, nothing like that.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: Any confusion or memory loss?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: No.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: Any neck pain?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Uhm, not neck pain but like just below my neck, like my back, upper back hurts as well.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK, and, any weight loss recently?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Uhm, no, I don't, I don't think so.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: Any excessive fatigue?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Yeah, I have been feeling pretty tired and just, uh, I haven't even gone to work this whole week, just kind of laying in bed honestly with all the pain and the fever and headaches, just yeah, it's exhausting.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK, any changes in your hair, nails or skin, like rashes?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: No, nothing that I've noticed.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: How about changes in your vision or hearing?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: No.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: No OK, how about a stuffy nose or runny nose?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Uh, I do feel a bit more stuffy like today, but there's no like runny nose or anything like that, but I do feel a bit more pressure and stuffiness in my face today.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK, OK, how about changes in smell or taste?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Yeah, I think, just last night dinner, it was just kind of a funky like, different taste. I couldn't really tell, uh, everything was kind of a bit bland. Yeah, I think my taste buds are acting all weird too.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK, um, any coughing or shortness of breath?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Uh, no, no, I haven't been coughing or no shortness of breath at all.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK and how about wheezing?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: No, no wheezing?

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK, any chest pain?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: No.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: How about feeling like your heart's racing?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: No, nothing like that.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: No, OK. Any swelling that you've noticed in your limbs?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: No.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: No, ok. Any issues with your bowel movements or urine?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: No, nothing.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK, how about nausea or vomiting?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: uh no, no nausea or vomiting.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK, and those were all the questions I had about your symptoms. Are you otherwise healthy or do you have any longstanding medical conditions?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Yeah, I have a couple conditions that I see my family doctor for. I do have diabetes, then I have high cholesterol. I also have this thing called fatty liver but that's that's about it, and a high blood pressure.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK, when were you diagnosed with all of these things?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Yeah, probably like, it all kind of went down in my 40s. I did gain a lot of weight at some point during my 40s and that's when all these things started happening.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK, so you said diabetes, high blood pressure, fatty liver, and sorry, what was the other one?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: High cholesterol.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: High cholesterol, OK, are you on medications for all of these things?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Yeah so I am on a statin medication for the cholesterol, then I'm on metformin, and then I'm on a blood pressure medication as well. I can't recall the name. Uh, so yeah, those are the medications that I'm on.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK. And do you take your medications regularly as prescribed?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Yeah, I don't miss any doses.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK, good. And, are you up to date with all your immunizations?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Yeah, I think so.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK, good. Do you have any allergies?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: No, no allergies.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: How about family history of lung conditions or heart conditions?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Yes, I have a pretty significant family history for heart conditions. My father passed away from a heart attack in his 50s. My mom has high blood pressure. Diabetes is also pretty big in my family as well.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK, well I'm sorry to hear that. Any cancers in the family?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: No, no cancers.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK, do you smoke?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: I used to when I was in my 30s. I quit a pretty long time ago.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK, how much did you smoke before that?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: I probably smoked up until I was 35, so for probably like 10 years from 25 to 35 and probably smoked a pack a day at that time.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK, yeah, and do you drink alcohol?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: I've been told like, not to for my liver, but I sometimes maybe have the rare red wine maybe once a month.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: Once a month, OK, any other recreational drugs?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: No, no recreational drugs.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK, no recreational drugs, and where do you live right now?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: I just live with my wife in an apartment in the city, and yeah.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK, any old carpet, dust, mold, anything that is concerning from that standpoint?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Nope.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: No, and have you been in contact with anyone who's been sick recently?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Not that I know of.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: Do you still go to work?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: I just have like a desk job. I have my own room. It's not like, I don't see too many people and like, when I do I'm wearing a mask so I don't think so.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK.

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: I have stopped going to work though like, just in case.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK, good and have you traveled to anywhere recently?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: No, we've been pretty homebound.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: Pretty homebound, OK, alright, well that's good and those are all the questions that I had for you. Did you have any questions for myself?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Yeah, I don't know, what do you think is causing all of this?

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: Yeah, it sounds like you have some sort of infection, so the first thing we need to rule out is covid, of course. So we'll do a swab and those swabs should come back to you in about 24 to 48 hours and until then, it's important that you do isolate and you isolate for 14 days at least, and that includes from other people at home. And if those swabs come back negative, you could possibly have like, another infection. But if your symptoms worsen, like you start getting neurological deficits like weakness or seizures or anything like that, you should come back to the ER and we'll get that checked out. And, so that's where we'll start for now, because your presentation is acute, we think it's likely infection related.

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: OK, that sounds good to me and should I be staying in my own room or anything like that at home?

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: Yeah, if you can like, it's recommended that you try to isolate in your own room for the next 14 days because your symptoms do overlap with that of covid, yeah.

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: OK, sounds good.Thank you.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: Yeah, no worries, take care.

utterances.speaker: control
utterances.text: Add differential diagnosis
